head.title: The Way It Is: End the Dumbing Down of TV

hedline.hl1: The Way It Is: End the Dumbing Down of TV

abstract.p: Walter Cronkite letter, prompted by Chicago television station WBBM's decision to cancel its news program experiment, laments dumbing down of media

block.p: Re ''Chicago News Experiment Is Calling It Quits'' (news article, Oct. 31):
Re ''Chicago News Experiment Is Calling It Quits'' (news article, Oct. 31):

Your article is disheartening to those many of us in television journalism who had hoped that WBBM-TV's format would be successful and lead the way to a wide adoption of more serious and informative news broadcasts.

The critics are right that WBBM's program had production flaws that probably contributed to its failure to gain ratings satisfactory to management, but there is a more serious cause for its failure -- one that plays right into the presidential election's concentration on the failure of our educational system.
Television, in news and entertainment, has suffered a huge dumbing down because that is where the audience is.
Television, which is primarily a for-profit enterprise, can only realize this objective by appealing to the lowest common denominator.
If we want better television (and newspapers, magazines and movies), a dumbing down of the media is not going to do it.
Instead, we had better look to a smartening up of the people. That would produce a more discerning and demanding audience.
